header.title: Dotlibrary
text: Dot library is my very first library created and built with SDL2 and C++. Dot library is a graphics library that swiftly lets the user set up a graphical interface to start implementing their code. Utilizing a grid of squares which each and one can be colored individually the library is easy to understand and requires little knowledge of graphical programming to use.

aside.title: Company
aside.text: No company assoicated with this project

sections.title: Aim
text: The idea of this project first arose when I myself wanted to create a snake game. I noticed that there are some very good graphics libraries out there but they were all kind of complicated to understand and operate. The goal with Dot Library was to create a library which could easily display a grid of dots (pixels) that could be manipulated by the programmer using the library.

sections.title: Method
text: There is no clear development structure of this library since it has been worked on at different times. The project is highly agile and as I worked bugs were fixed and new features were implemented when they seemed fitting. However, the core of the project was to link the library to the media layer SDL2 and be able to communicate with its API. As SDL were connected the grid system could be evolved and established which led to the first release of the library. The grid system is the raw core of the application but there has been a lot of new features added, such as further integration with SDL2 window, optimization improvements an so on.

sections.title: Result
text: The Dot library project finished by meeting the aim of the application, to create a library for people to use which were easy to use and didn't require too much code. However, performance could have been massively improved and one problem with the library was that even though it is easy to use it arguably much harder to install. The installation of this library requires the programmer to first install SDL2, by following instructions strictly and later adding the library itself. The library was also statically compiled which meant the programmer had to connect a .lib file to make everything work.

sections.title: Disscussion
text: If I knew what I know today when I developed Dot library I would base my library on SDL2 but instead something lower to enable higher performance capacity. Secondly, it is incredibly much difficult to install a library the way I created it statically. Preferably a library such as Dotlib would be headeronly, enabling programmers to skip installation and connecting lib files to compiler input and so on and instead simply just drag and drop the files to their project.

header.title: Physics simulator
text: The physics simulator is an application made to view and understand force on multiple objects. The application lets the user summon spheres which when started will begin interacting with each other.

aside.title: Company
aside.text: No company assoicated with this project

sections.title: Aim
text: The aim of this program was to simulate gravitational forces between objects in order to get a deeper understanding of the physics behind forces. The requirements for the program were to have a working physics engine that could handle all objects, have some form of graphics that could visually present the objects and display the properties of each object such as mass, dimensions, and velocity.

sections.title: Method
text: The methods of this project were built on physics classes in high school. When developing the engine I used my knowledge I recently gained from the lessons and combined the relations between a position, a velocity, and an acceleration. When the engine worked between two objects I implemented the feature to add multiple objects, all interacting with each other. This was as simple as a nested for loop matching all objects with each other and applying the required equation.

When the base of the project was established I started working on a new feature which was the possibility to zoom in and out and move freely in the universe. Earlier when the objects moved out of screen there was no way of returning them unless teleporting them back. However, with the feature to zoom in and out, it enabled for a new specter of possibilities in the simulator.

sections.title: Result
text: The result was above expectation. I went from having two objects that could interact with each other to 50+. The zoom and moving algorithm were hard to establish but when they worked they literally gave the simulator a whole new dimension of possibilities. However, the frontend part of the application could have been executed better. The application does not scale and does not support different screen sizes. The graphical part of the program is only there to the functional part and there is no user experience at all neither any design to make the program look good. With that said the application still meets it's goals since it's original purpose was to simulate movement of objects which it does perfectly.

sections.title: Disscussion
text: I learned a lot by doing this project, from different aspects. After I created the simple engine I better understood gravity and all objects in the universe helped me improve my OOP skills. For my next project I will try to either do something that I know I can finish by myself, or collaborate with someone to make the design part for me since it a little unfortunate that I can't finish the program fully because I do not want to work with the user experience.

header.title: Erislaw webpage
text: Eris law is a Swedish law firm operating from Stockholm. In this project, I got hired to design and publish their site www.erislaw.se. The webpage contains newsfeed, about page, a home page, contact forms and much more, using Joomla as a foundation for the backend.

sections.title: Aim
text: Unlike other projects I do this one was not on request by myself but instead by the firm Eris law. The goal here was to create a fully functional webpage, with functionalities such possibilities to create and edit articles and items published on the site without changing any code. The site would have all default aspects of sites, such as fully functional navigation, internal links, footers and so on and lastly, a good looking frontend had to be designed.

sections.title: Method
text: Since this project was my first ever interaction with web development at all I choose to adopt Joomla as my development tool for the structure of the project. Even though the Joomla platform is developed to ease the burden on the developer it still requires a lot of practice to understand the Joomla infrastructure and management of items. This took me a good amount of time and as I learned my way through the platform I started building the foundation of the site. The whole project was split into two parts, firstly creating the site itself with all its content, pages and functionalities and secondly apply design and user experience. I noticed relatively quickly that Joomla is rather efficient at creating structures on a site and when I could understand the tool the site grew very fast. However, the design part was a lot more difficuly for multiple reasons, I had never designed a webpage before and therefore had no earlier references to use in order to determine if something looked good or bad and Joomla becomes massively more difficult when trying to change certain properties not supported by the platform.

When the base of the project was established I started working on a new feature which was the possibility to zoom in and out and move freely in the universe. Later in the project, a designer was included as a compliment to fix certain uncertainties and problems. With the tips received from the designer, the page took form and could be finalized with a good looking interface.

sections.title: Result
text: The result of the project turned out successfully. All requirements were met such as possibilities all pages, possibility to edit and create new articles with a built-in interface and of course a design for the page. This project did not come with a clear deadline and could, therefore, be finished on time.

sections.title: Disscussion
text: Having finished this project I can say that I've learned a huge amount of things. This project forced me to understand, design, backend and a specific platform simultaneously. I had a lot of problems doing some very specific changes for the design and one of the things I've learned for the future is to not use a platform for my future sites. I realize now that my need to be able to access all parts of the system does not work very well with a platform that builds stuff for you. Joomla is an excellent tool for creating a webpage swiftly and without to much design but when the page gets requirements on how it's supposed to look it becomes harder and harder to work with a platform. However, using a platform such as Joomla saved me a bunch of time managing databases and creating systems which gave specific users privileges to edit articles and so on.

header.title: Arrender
text: Arrender.app is a project created to simplify planning and "get togethers" by giving the user a simple and intuitive application with visual presentations of when people are available. This project is one of the largest projects I've worked on and has brought me much knowledge in the web-stack. Not to mention that this project was my first serious collaborative project, made together with Martin Ryberg Laude.

sections.title: Aim
text: This project was initially born from the idea that it could be a lot easier to organize meetings than it currently is. Today a meeting is generally organized via mails conversations where multiple people send their available time back and forth to find the best suited time. This was something we wanted to solve with the project we call Arrender.

The idea was to create a shared calendar that all participants in the meeting could see and add their information to and then let the system find the best time. Another important aspect for us was to minimize the friction for people to interact with the product. Therefore we wanted to make it possible for people that didn't have an account to also participate in meetings, a feature we'd later call "guest users".

sections.title: Disscussion
